claim: A task started on Monday and lasting 10 business days ends next Wednesday

supporting.text: Business days typically exclude weekends, so a 10-business-day period starting on Monday would span two full weeks plus two additional days, ending on the following Wednesday.

attacks.text: Business days typically exclude weekends, so a 10-business-day period starting on Monday would span two full weeks plus two additional days, ending on the following Wednesday.
If there is a public holiday within the 10-business-day period, the end date would be pushed to Thursday instead of Wednesday.
Public holidays are region-specific and not universally applicable, so the original assumption holds unless specified otherwise.
Some countries or industries consider Saturday as a business day, which would change the end date to Tuesday instead of Wednesday.
The claim specifies 'business days' in the conventional sense (Monday-Friday), making the Saturday-inclusion scenario irrelevant unless explicitly stated.

supporting.text: Counting 10 business days from Monday includes the next two Fridays, with the 10th day landing on the second Wednesday after the start date.

attacks.text: Counting 10 business days from Monday includes the next two Fridays, with the 10th day landing on the second Wednesday after the start date.
If a public holiday occurs within the 10 business days, the end date would shift to Thursday, not Wednesday.
Public holidays are typically excluded from business days by default, so the original calculation remains correct unless specified otherwise.
Different regions define business days differently (e.g., some exclude Saturdays), which could alter the end date.
In most international business contexts, Monday to Friday are standard business days, making the original calculation widely applicable.

supporting.text: Standard business calendars count Monday to Friday as business days, so 10 business days starting Monday would skip two weekends and end on the subsequent Wednesday.

attacks.text: Standard business calendars count Monday to Friday as business days, so 10 business days starting Monday would skip two weekends and end on the subsequent Wednesday.
If a public holiday falls within the 10 business days, the end date would be delayed by one day for each holiday, potentially shifting the end date beyond Wednesday.
Most business calendars account for public holidays and adjust deadlines accordingly, so the original calculation remains valid unless specified otherwise.
If the task starts late on Monday (e.g., after business hours), some organizations may consider the first business day to be Tuesday, shifting the end date to Thursday.
Standard business practices typically count the entire day of Monday as a business day regardless of start time, unless explicitly defined otherwise.

supporting.text: A 10-business-day duration starting on Monday includes the next two weeks' worth of weekdays, with the final day being the second Wednesday after the start.

attacks.text: A 10-business-day duration starting on Monday includes the next two weeks' worth of weekdays, with the final day being the second Wednesday after the start.
Business days exclude weekends and holidays, so if there is a holiday within the 10-day period, the end date would shift to the next business day.
In most standard business contexts, holidays are predefined and accounted for in scheduling, so the original calculation remains accurate unless an unexpected holiday occurs.
Different regions or companies may define 'business days' differently, potentially including or excluding certain days, which could alter the end date.
Standard international business practices typically follow a Monday-to-Friday workweek, making the original argument broadly applicable unless specified otherwise.
